heat_capacityÂ¶

class thermosteam.functors.heat_capacity.Lastovka_Shaw(*args, **kwargs)[source]Â¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that calcuates gas molar heat capacity (Cn.g; in J/mol/K) using the Lastovka Shaw equation, as described in [1].

Parameters
MWNone

Molecular weight [g/mol].

similarity_variableNone

Heat capacity similarity variable [-].

iscyclic_aliphaticbool

Whether a chemical is cyclic aliphatic [-].

Notes

The ideal-gas heat capacity (Cn.g; in J/mol/K) is given by:

\[\begin{split}C_n^0 = MW \left(A_2 + \frac{A_1 - A_2}{1 + \exp(\frac{\alpha-A_3}{A_4})}\right) + (B_{11} + B_{12}\alpha)\left(-\frac{(C_{11} + C_{12}\alpha)}{T}\right)^2 \frac{\exp(-(C_{11} + C_{12}\alpha)/T)}{[1-\exp(-(C_{11}+C_{12}\alpha)/T)]^2}\\ + (B_{21} + B_{22}\alpha)\left(-\frac{(C_{21} + C_{22}\alpha)}{T}\right)^2 \frac{\exp(-(C_{21} + C_{22}\alpha)/T)}{[1-\exp(-(C_{21}+C_{22}\alpha)/T)]^2}\end{split}\]

Original model is in terms of J/g/K, but is translated to molar heat capacity in J/mol/K.

A1 = 0.58, A2 = 1.25, A3 = 0.17338003, A4 = 0.014, B11 = 0.73917383, B12 = 8.88308889, C11 = 1188.28051, C12 = 1813.04613, B21 = 0.0483019, B22 = 4.35656721, C21 = 2897.01927, C22 = 5987.80407.

References

1

Lastovka, Vaclav, and John M. Shaw. âPredictive Correlations for Ideal Gas Heat Capacities of Pure Hydrocarbons and Petroleum Fractions.â Fluid Phase Equilibria 356 (October 25, 2013): 338-370. doi:10.1016/j.fluid.2013.07.023.

Examples

Compute the heat capacity of Methane at 300 K:

>>> f_Cng = Lastovka_Shaw(MW=16.043,
...                       similarity_variable=0.31166,
...                       iscyclic_aliphatic=False)
>>> f_Cng
Functor: Lastovka_Shaw(T, P=None) -> Cn.g [J/mol/K]
 MW: 16.043 g/mol
 similarity_variable: 0.31166
 iscyclic_aliphatic: 0
>>> f_Cng(T=400.0)
33.91574477458602
class thermosteam.functors.heat_capacity.TRCCn(*args, **kwargs)[source]Â¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that calcuates gas molar heat capacity (Cn.g; in J/mol/K) using the TRCCn equation, as described in [1].

Parameters
a0, a1, a2, a3, a4, a5, a6, a7float

Regressed coefficients.

Notes

The ideal gas heat capacity (Cn.g; J/mol/K) is given by:

\[ \begin{align}\begin{aligned}C_n = R\left(a_0 + (a_1/T^2) \exp(-a_2/T) + a_3 y^2 + (a_4 - a_5/(T-a_7)^2 )y^j \right)\\y = \frac{T-a_7}{T+a_6} \text{ for } T > a_7 \text{ otherwise } 0\end{aligned}\end{align} \]

j is set to 8. Analytical integrals are available for this expression.

References

1

Kabo, G. J., and G. N. Roganov. Thermodynamics of Organic Compounds in the Gas State, Volume II: V. 2. College Station, Tex: CRC Press, 1994.

Examples

Calculate the heat capacity of Methane at 300 K:

>>> f_Cng = TRCCn(4.0, 22350000, 2018, 32.767, -31.098, 1346090000, 1229, 473)
>>> f_Cng
Functor: TRCCn(T, P=None) -> Cn.g [J/mol/K]
 a0: 4
 a1: 2.235e+07
 a2: 2018
 a3: 32.767
 a4: -31.098
 a5: 1.3461e+09
 a6: 1229
 a7: 473
>>> f_Cng(300)
35.73249522521754
class thermosteam.functors.heat_capacity.Poling(*args, **kwargs)[source]Â¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that calcuates gas molar heat capacity (Cn.g; in J/mol/K) using the Poling equation.

Parameters
a, b, c, d, efloat

Regressed coefficients.

Notes

The ideal gas heat capacity (Cn.g; J/mol/K) is given by:

\[C_n = R*(a + bT + cT^2 + dT^3 + eT^4)\]

The data is based on the Poling data bank

Examples

Compute the gas heat capacity of Methane at 300 K:

>>> f_Cng = Poling(a=4.568, b=-0.008975, c=3.631e-05, d=-3.407e-08, e=1.091e-11)
>>> f_Cng
Functor: Poling(T, P=None) -> Cn.g [J/mol/K]
 a: 4.568
 b: -0.008975
 c: 3.631e-05
 d: -3.407e-08
 e: 1.091e-11
>>> f_Cng(300)
35.85096123688382
class thermosteam.functors.heat_capacity.Rowlinson_Poling(*args, **kwargs)[source]Â¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that calcuates liquid molar heat capacity (Cn.l; in J/mol/K) using the Rowlinson Poling equation, as described in [1].

Parameters
TcNone

Critical point temperature [K].

ÏNone

Acentric factor [-].

Cn_gfloat

Regressed coefficients.

Notes

The heat capacity of a liquid is given by:

\[\frac{Cn^{L} - Cn^{g}}{R} = 1.586 + \frac{0.49}{1-T_r} + \omega\left[ 4.2775 + \frac{6.3(1-T_r)^{1/3}}{T_r} + \frac{0.4355}{1-T_r}\right]\]

This equation is not too accurate. Poling compared 212 substances, and found error at 298K larger than 10% for 18 of them, mostly associating. Of the other 194 compounds, AARD is 2.5%.

References

1

Poling, Bruce E. The Properties of Gases and Liquids. 5th edition. New York: McGraw-Hill Professional, 2000.

Examples

Compute the liquid heat capacity of methane at 100 K:

>>> Cn_g = Poling(a=4.568, b=-0.008975, c=3.631e-05,
                  d=-3.407e-08, e=1.091e-11)
>>> f_Cnl = Rowlinson_Poling(Tc=190.564, Ï=0.008, Cn_g=Cn_g)
Functor: Rowlinson_Poling(T, P=None) -> Cn.l [J/mol/K]
 Tc: 190.56 K
 Ï: 0.008
 Cn_g: Poling(T, P=None) -> J/mol/K
>>> f_Cnl(100)
55.99104104081243
class thermosteam.functors.heat_capacity.Dadgostar_Shaw(*args, **kwargs)[source]Â¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that calcuates liquid molar heat capacity (Cn.l; in J/mol/K) using the Dadgostar Shaw equation, as described in [1].

Parameters
similarity_variableNone

Heat capacity similarity variable [-].

MWNone

Molecular weight [g/mol].

Notes

The liquid heat capacity is given by:

\[C_{p} = 24.5(a_{11}\alpha + a_{12}\alpha^2)+ (a_{21}\alpha + a_{22}\alpha^2)T +(a_{31}\alpha + a_{32}\alpha^2)T^2 C_n = MW \cdot Cp\]

Many restrictions on its use.

Original model is in terms of J/g/K, but it has been modified to give molar heat capacity in J/mol/K.

a11 = -0.3416; a12 = 2.2671; a21 = 0.1064; a22 = -0.3874l; a31 = -9.8231E-05; a32 = 4.182E-04

References

1

Dadgostar, Nafiseh, and John M. Shaw. âA Predictive Correlation for the Constant-Pressure Specific Heat Capacity of Pure and Ill-Defined Liquid Hydrocarbons.â Fluid Phase Equilibria 313 (January 15, 2012): 211-226. doi:10.1016/j.fluid.2011.09.015.

Examples

>>> Dadgostar_Shaw(355.6, 0.139)
1802.5291501191516
class thermosteam.functors.heat_capacity.Zabransky_Quasi_Polynomial(*args, **kwargs)[source]Â¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that calcuates liquid molar heat capacity (Cn.l; in J/mol/K) using the Zabransky Quasi Polynomial equation, as described in [1].

Parameters
TcNone

Critical point temperature [K].

a1, a2, a3, a4, a5, a6float

Regressed coefficients.

Notes

The liquid heat capacity is given by:

\[\frac{C_n}{R}=A_1\ln(1-T_r) + \frac{A_2}{1-T_r} + \sum_{j=0}^m A_{j+3} T_r^j\]

Used only for isobaric heat capacities, not saturation heat capacities. Designed for reasonable extrapolation behavior caused by using the reduced critical temperature. Used by the authors of [1] when critical temperature was available for the fluid.

References

1(1,2)

Zabransky, M., V. Ruzicka Jr, V. Majer, and Eugene S. Domalski. Heat Capacity of Liquids: Critical Review and Recommended Values. 2 Volume Set. Washington, D.C.: Amer Inst of Physics, 1996.

class thermosteam.functors.heat_capacity.Zabransky_Cubic(*args, **kwargs)[source]Â¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that calcuates liquid molar heat capacity (Cn.l; in J/mol/K) using the Zabransky Cubic equation, as described in [1].

Parameters
a1, a2, a3, a4float

Regressed coefficients.

Notes

The liquid heat capacity is given by:

\[\frac{C}{R}=\sum_{j=0}^3 A_{j+1} \left(\frac{T}{100}\right)^j\]

References

1

Zabransky, M., V. Ruzicka Jr, V. Majer, and Eugene S. Domalski. Heat Capacity of Liquids: Critical Review and Recommended Values. 2 Volume Set. Washington, D.C.: Amer Inst of Physics, 1996.

class thermosteam.functors.heat_capacity.Perry_151(*args, **kwargs)[source]Â¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that calcuates solid molar heat capacity (Cn.s; in J/mol/K) using the Perry 151 equation, as described in [1].

Parameters
a, b, c, dfloat

Regressed coefficients.

Notes

The solid heat capacity is given by:

\[C_n = 4.184 (a + bT + \frac{c}{T^2} + dT^2)\]

Coefficients are listed in section 2, table 151 of [1]. Note that the original model was in a Calorie basis, but has been translated to Joules.

References

1(1,2)

Green, Don, and Robert Perry. Perryâs Chemical Engineersâ Handbook, Eighth Edition. McGraw-Hill Professional, 2007.
